alerts.name: X-Content-Type-Options Header Missing
alerts.desc: The Anti-MIME-Sniffing header X-Content-Type-Options was not set to 'nosniff'. This allows older versions of Internet Explorer and Chrome to perform MIME-sniffing on the response body, potentially causing the response body to be interpreted and displayed as a content type other than the declared content type. Current (early 2014) and legacy versions of Firefox will use the declared content type (if one is set), rather than performing MIME-sniffing.
alerts.solution:
Ensure that the application/web server sets the Content-Type header appropriately, and that it sets the X-Content-Type-Options header to 'nosniff' for all web pages.

If possible, ensure that the end user uses a standards-compliant and modern web browser that does not perform MIME-sniffing at all, or that can be directed by the web application/web server to not perform MIME-sniffing.
alerts.otherinfo:
This issue still applies to error type pages (401, 403, 500, etc.) as those pages are often still affected by injection issues, in which case there is still concern for browsers sniffing pages away from their actual content type.

At "High" threshold this scan rule will not alert on client or server error responses.

alerts.name: Permissions Policy Header Not Set
alerts.desc: Permissions Policy Header is an added layer of security that helps to restrict from unauthorized access or usage of browser/client features by web resources. This policy ensures the user privacy by limiting or specifying the features of the browsers can be used by the web resources. Permissions Policy provides a set of standard HTTP headers that allow website owners to limit which features of browsers can be used by the page such as camera, microphone, location, full screen etc.
alerts.solution: Ensure that your web server, application server, load balancer, etc. is configured to set the Permissions-Policy header.

alerts.alert: Incomplete or No Cache-control Header Set
alerts.name: Incomplete or No Cache-control Header Set
alerts.desc: The cache-control header has not been set properly or is missing, allowing the browser and proxies to cache content.
alerts.solution: Whenever possible ensure the cache-control HTTP header is set with no-cache, no-store, must-revalidate.

alerts.name: Retrieved from Cache
alerts.desc: The content was retrieved from a shared cache. If the response data is sensitive, personal or user-specific, this may result in sensitive information being leaked. In some cases, this may even result in a user gaining complete control of the session of another user, depending on the configuration of the caching components in use in their environment. This is primarily an issue where caching servers such as "proxy" caches are configured on the local network. This configuration is typically found in corporate or educational environments, for instance.
alerts.solution:
Validate that the response does not contain sensitive, personal or user-specific information. If it does, consider the use of the following HTTP response headers, to limit, or prevent the content being stored and retrieved from the cache by another user:

Cache-Control: no-cache, no-store, must-revalidate, private

Pragma: no-cache

Expires: 0

This configuration directs both HTTP 1.0 and HTTP 1.1 compliant caching servers to not store the response, and to not retrieve the response (without validation) from the cache, in response to a similar request.
alerts.otherinfo: The presence of the 'Age' header indicates that that a HTTP/1.1 compliant caching server is in use.

alerts.name: Sub Resource Integrity Attribute Missing
alerts.desc: The integrity attribute is missing on a script or link tag served by an external server. The integrity tag prevents an attacker who have gained access to this server from injecting a malicious content.
alerts.solution: Provide a valid integrity attribute to the tag.

alerts.name: Timestamp Disclosure - Unix
alerts.desc: A timestamp was disclosed by the application/web server - Unix
alerts.solution: Manually confirm that the timestamp data is not sensitive, and that the data cannot be aggregated to disclose exploitable patterns.

alerts.name: Storable but Non-Cacheable Content
alerts.desc: The response contents are storable by caching components such as proxy servers, but will not be retrieved directly from the cache, without validating the request upstream, in response to similar requests from other users.

alerts.name: Information Disclosure - Suspicious Comments
alerts.desc: The response appears to contain suspicious comments which may help an attacker. Note: Matches made within script blocks or files are against the entire content not only comments.
alerts.solution: Remove all comments that return information that may help an attacker and fix any underlying problems they refer to.
alerts.otherinfo: The following pattern was used: \bQUERY\b and was detected in the element starting with: "

alerts.name: X-Frame-Options Header Not Set
alerts.desc: X-Frame-Options header is not included in the HTTP response to protect against 'ClickJacking' attacks.
alerts.solution: Most modern Web browsers support the X-Frame-Options HTTP header. Ensure it's set on all web pages returned by your site (if you expect the page to be framed only by pages on your server (e.g. it's part of a FRAMESET) then you'll want to use SAMEORIGIN, otherwise if you never expect the page to be framed, you should use DENY. Alternatively consider implementing Content Security Policy's "frame-ancestors" directive.

alerts.alert: Content Security Policy (CSP) Header Not Set
alerts.name: Content Security Policy (CSP) Header Not Set
alerts.desc: Content Security Policy (CSP) is an added layer of security that helps to detect and mitigate certain types of attacks, including Cross Site Scripting (XSS) and data injection attacks. These attacks are used for everything from data theft to site defacement or distribution of malware. CSP provides a set of standard HTTP headers that allow website owners to declare approved sources of content that browsers should be allowed to load on that page — covered types are JavaScript, CSS, HTML frames, fonts, images and embeddable objects such as Java applets, ActiveX, audio and video files.
alerts.solution: Ensure that your web server, application server, load balancer, etc. is configured to set the Content-Security-Policy header, to achieve optimal browser support: "Content-Security-Policy" for Chrome 25+, Firefox 23+ and Safari 7+, "X-Content-Security-Policy" for Firefox 4.0+ and Internet Explorer 10+, and "X-WebKit-CSP" for Chrome 14+ and Safari 6+.
